item.description: Namaste, Welcome to Jaipur(known as Pink City), the Capital of...
item.content:encoded:
Namaste, Welcome to Jaipur(known as Pink City), the Capital of the Rajasthan States of India.

1. Hawa Mahal Castle

Rajput Royal Ladies in those days strictly followed the Pardah system, protecting themselves not to be seen by any stranger in public. The construction of Hawa Mahal Castle built in 1799 extension of the Royal City Palace nearby allows the royal ladies to enjoy from everyday street scenes to royal processions on the street from the small window without being seen. It has honeycomb-shaped and beautifully carved 953 windows that allow the breeze to blow through the palace, suitable to tackle summer heat in that area. This Hawa Mahal Castle(the Palace of Breeze) is now the identity of Jaipur(Top Attractions) among travellers. 

Location: Hawa Mahal Rd, Badi Choupad, J.D.A. Market, Pink City, Jaipur, Rajasthan 302002
Directions: Google Map, Apple Map
Opening Hours: Between 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM Daily (Visiting Hours)
Closed On: It does not close on public holidays or Sunday
Entry Price: Indian ₹10/- Per Person + Foreigner ₹50/- Per Person
Website: hawa-mahal.com

2. Forts & Palaces

A. The City Palace

It was built by Sawai Jai Singh holds the credit of being the founder of Jaipur his residing throne. Started the construction of the palace way in the 17th century as he wanted to shift the capital of the state from Amber to Jaipur. Raja Man Singh II was the last ruler of this dynasty to hold the throne in this palace. The beautiful structure was designed by architects Vidyadhar Bhattacharya and Samuel Swinton Jacob who brought a European influence to the design. This Opulent 18th-century palace now opens the door to the public as a museum(private royal residence not for the public).

Location: Gangori Bazaar, J.D.A. Market, Pink City, Jaipur, Rajasthan 302002
Directions: Google Map, Apple Map
Opening Hours: Between 9:30 AM to 7:00 PM Daily (Visiting Hours)
Entry Price: Indian ₹300/- Per Person + Foreigner ₹700/- Per Person
Ticket: Online Ticket Buy
Website: royaljaipur.in

B. Amer Fort & Palace

The huge Amber Palace or Amer Fort sits atop a small hill. The fort has a number of sections, including the King’s quarters, the zenana (where the women lived), gardens, temples(including the diwan-e-aam, such mandir, and the Sheesh Mahal) etc. Amer Fort is also home to some underground tunnels that connect Amer to Jaigarh Fort. 

Location: Devisinghpura, Amer, Jaipur, Rajasthan 302001
Directions: Google Map, Apple Map
Opening Hours: Between 8:00 AM to 5:30 PM Daily (Visiting Hours)
Entry Price: Indian ₹100/- Per Person + Foreigner ₹500/- Per Person
Ticket: Online Ticket Buy
Website: tourism.rajasthan.gov.in/amber-palace.html

item.title: Bonedi Barir Kojagori Laxmi Puja Kolkata
item.dc:creator: Sukanta Pal
item.description: One of the most popular festivals in West Bengal/Kolkata is...
item.content:encoded:
One of the most popular festivals in West Bengal/Kolkata is Durga Puja, famous for its Celebration and Economical boast. In December 2021 ‘Durga Puja in Kolkata’ was inscribed in UNESCO’s Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity, so this Year Durga Puja 2022 first time celebrated after receiving UNESCO’s Intangible Cultural Heritage Tag, though this year’s celebration started before mahalaya but the vibe was not there at all. The aftermath of major annual festivals or king of the festival in terms of popularity, grandeur and showcase for international tourism in Kolkata(Calcutta) ends followed by next year’s Durga Puja 2023 Dates announced. After that begins Kojagori Lakshmi Pooja or Laxmi Puja (মা লক্ষ্মী or Laksmi) knocking next door. This puja basically happened in almost every household and a few Bonedi bari’s of Kolkata take it next label.

Some pandal or Barowari Puja Committee Clubs hold this puja as well because it’s a few days after the Durga puja, they do this puja in the same Dismantle pandal where the Durga idol was there. They bought idols at the same time as they bought the Durga idol (extra ordered for the Laxmi idol too. In the same pandal), they worshipped Laxmi Puja on a very small scale just for the sake of it. This way they do two pujas back to back one after another, দুগ্গা দুগ্গা করে লক্ষ্মী এলো ঘরে (Dugga Dugga kore lakkhi Elo Ghore) be like. Kojagori Lakshmi Puja or Lakhi puja whatever name you call it, this Kojagori Laxmi Puja is worshipped in Bengali Hindu homes and commercial establishments as the goddess of wealth. These Puja attractions are White Color Alpona given by women (or anyone), preparing Bhog like Kichuri, making sweets Naru (Sweets made of Coconut) Narkol Chire, Sinni, Murki and many other delicious food items. Lakshmi Pooja performs in the evening of Sharad Purnima (Full Moon Day) followed by Conch Sounds and reciting Lakshmi Pacnachli. 

Sharad Purnima (also known as Kumara Purnima(କୁମାର ପୂର୍ଣ୍ଣିମା ), Kojagiri Purnima, Navanna Purnima, or Kaumudi Purnima is a harvest festival celebrated on the full moon day of the Hindu lunar month of Ashvin (September to October), marking the end of the monsoon season. On this auspicious day, many divine pairs like Radha Krishna, Shiva Parvati, and Lakshmi Narayan are worshipped along with the moon and are offered flowers and kheer (sweet dish made of rice and milk). Deities in temples are usually dressed in white colour signifying the brightness of the moon. Many people observe full-day fasting on this day. This day is celebrated differently in different parts of the country. In Odisha, on this day unmarried women keep fast with the popular belief of getting their suitable groom(kumara).

  1. Howrah Bose Bari

Kojagori Laxmi Puja Festival Dates by Year

This festival starts with maidens welcoming the sun god just at sunrise with a coconut-leaf-made-vessel called ‘kula’ filled with fried paddy containing 7 fruits like coconut, banana, cucumber, betel nut, sugar-cane, guava followed by ‘Aarti’. In the evening they break their fast by preparing a dish containing the fried paddy of the morning along with the fruits, curd, and jaggery to offer the moon god before the ‘tulsi’ plant. After this maidens play games and sing songs under the light of the full moon. In many parts of Gujarat, Garba (a form of dance) takes place in the presence of moonlight. The Kojagari Purnima concerns the observance of the Kojagara Vrata. People perform this Vrata under the moonlight after fasting for the day. Lakshmi, the Hindu Goddess of Wealth, is significantly worshipped on this day as it is believed to be her birthday. Lord Indra, the God of Rains, along with his elephant Airavata is also worshipped. It is believed that on the night of Sharad Purnima, the raas (a form of dance) of Radha Krishna also takes place along with their gopis. 

The festivity is also known as ‘Bengal Lakshmi Puja’ or ‘Kojagari Purnima’. Goddess Lakshmi is the deity of wealth, happiness and prosperity and, it is believed that worshipping Goddess on the day of Ashwin Purnima, the devotees get blessed with abundant wealth, prosperity and good fortune. Many households don’t bring Protima or Lakshmi idol they do the puja on Permanent idol called kulodebota(কুলদেবতা) or Protisthito Thakur, some people do it in Lakshi Sora (লক্ষ্মী সরা) or Pot refers to, some do it another idol and some mix of both Laxmi idol and kulodebota. 9th Oct’22 আজ হিন্দুদের লক্ষ্মী পুজো। বৌদ্ধদের প্রবারণা পূর্ণিমা। মুসলিমদের ইদে মিলাদুন্নবী

Another Festival next Door (2021 Edition)

When you go after Durga puja in Kumartuli (World Biggest and famous Pottery or idol makers lives there) lots of Laxmi idol, Pot or Sora are for sale along with accessories like jewellery, saree, alpona sticker and many more items that required for decoration or indirectly essential items for puja. This year 2021 after covid-19 lots of buyers visits kumartuli because now most peoples are vaccinated and case are low, because of rain people also buy plastic to cover the idol after purchasing it, so that they can safely bring it home without being drenched by water. This festival for 2 days, day after puja they immersed the idol on the Ganges and those who have a permanent idol and others they don’t do the immersion part.

Laksmi Puja’22 by Aloke Kumar

Lakṣmī puja is the most neglected and taken for granted puja in the Hindu Almanac. Since she has just visited us accompanying her mother in the Sharadotsav and coming back on the fifth day after returning to Kailash, her position is somewhat eroded like the married daughter coming home too early. Though she is worshipped daily in Bengali Hindu homes and commercial establishments as the goddess of wealth, she is given a step motherly treatment in the Sarbojinin puja. Her puja in the pandals are a leftover of funds from the worship of her mother Durga and she is not given the pride of place to either create a new pandal or given the due which she deserves. Much of this neglect is subterfuged under the guise of muted decor and puja as Lakṣmī is believed to be in favour of ‘calm and quiet’. But that is just a lame excuse and she knows it too. She bears us no grudge In the traditional Bengali home she is worshiped on the day of Diwali when her alter image, the OLakṣmī is driven out and Lakṣmī is ushered in. It was left to the migrants of East Bengal to celebrate Lakṣmī puja on Kojagiri Purnima and hoist her in the exalted position. First, to worship her in the Lakṣmī ‘sara’ and then moving to the idol. Having lost everything in the partition of 1947 and making the other part of Bengal their home, they continued their reverence, praying to give them prosperity. She did not disappoint them and showered them with her blessings. Seeing this their Western brethren followed suit. Lakṣmī is the Hindu Goddess of wealth, prosperity, both material and spiritual, fortune, and the embodiment of beauty. She is also worshipped as the consort of Vishnu. She is also known as Mahalakshmi, is said to bring good luck and is believed to protect her devotees from all kinds of misery and money-related sorrows. In Bengal, Lakṣmī is worshiped in autumn when the moon is full, the brightest night of the year. It is believed that she showers wealth on this night. She, along with her bahana, the great white owl, descends to earth and takes away the darkness of poverty, stagnation, anger, and laziness from our lives. Her bahana owl represents royalties, penetrating sight and intelligence. It serves as her mount over which she rides. Lakṣmī is also referred to as pranadayini,”giver of vital life-sustaining energy” who can turn a dull thing full of life. One of the most compelling stories in Hindu mythology is that of the Churning of the Milky Ocean. It is the story of the gods versus the demons and their fight to gain immortality. It also tells of the rebirth of Lakṣmī . Devas, gods, and asuras, demons, were both mortal at one time, in Hinduism. Amrit, the divine nectar that grants immortality, could only be obtained by churning the Kshirsagar,the Ocean of Milk. The devas and asuras both sought immortality and decided to churn the Kshirsagar. The samudra manthan commenced with the devas on one side and the asuras on the other. Vishnu incarnated as Kurma, the tortoise, and a mountain was placed on the tortoise as a churning pole. Vasuki, the great venom-spewing serpent, was wrapped around the mountain and used to churn the ocean. A host of divine celestial objects came up during the churning. Along with them emerged the goddess Lakṣmī, the daughter of Bhrigu and Khyaati. The last to come up was the Amrita. The avatar of Kurma, the tortoise, ended with this. Vishnu then took up the form of a beautiful maiden to distract the asuras and gave immortality to the devas. She is ‘shakti-roopa’ of ‘parabrahma’ or ‘adi dev narayan’ in the ‘Mahalakṣmī’ story. OLakṣmī the goddess of misfortune, is Lakṣmī’s elder sister, her alter image. Lakṣmī is called Shree or Thirumagal because she is endowed with six auspicious and divine qualities, or Gunas, and also because she is the source of strength even to Vishnu. She is commonly portrayed as a beautiful woman, standing on a lotus flower. There is her ‘bahana’ the white owl which accompanies her.

item.title: Men’s Essential Type of Bags
item.dc:creator: Sukanta Pal
item.description: Most essential types of bags for men in the Year...
item.content:encoded:
Most essential types of bags for men in the Year 2022 list down, everyday men’s activities and type of work with style bag industry shape in large. When it comes to fashion, accessories are as essential as clothing. A good-looking bag can make your casual outfits also look super stylish. As men’s fashion evolves constantly, there are a few styles of bags that are here to stay. Bags aren’t overlooked and labeled as a women’s accessory anymore. More and more bag styles emerge for men’s functional and fashion needs. Here are 5 Types Of Bags Every Man Needs To Add Functionality To His Wardrobe.

  1. BACKPACK  – 

One of the most famous men’s bags is the backpack, name suggests this bag seat on the back side that’s why called backpack. It’s designed for every lifestyle and features multiple storage compartments, zipper pockets and slots. You can find leather, fabric and all types of colors and designs in this highly versatile and affordable. The backpack is the most versatile of the items on this list and depending on your lifestyle, it could be a smart business-casual accessory, a daily go-anywhere bag for trips to the coffee shop, grocery store or gym or a piece of luggage. Most used for School, college, office, shooting and all. Buy Here

  1. CROSSBODY MESSENGER BAG or FANNY PACK –

A crossbody messenger bag is worn over one shoulder and positioned so it crosses over the man’s chest with the bag resting on his side. Some men prefer to carry the bag around their lower back instead of their side. There are many styles for this type of bag, but the most popular feature fold-over flap that is secured at the bottom of the bag with a zipper or closure. This type of bag can hold a laptop, cellphone, pens, papers, and any other items needed. Buy Here

  1. TOTE BAG – 

A large 2-handled open-topped bag (as of canvas). Famous for dangling from the arms of schlepping New Yorkers, tempting patrons at indie bookstores, or holding the groceries of eco-conscious fashionistas, tote bags have been a cultural phenomenon for generations. This versatile bag has evolved past its humble origins to become a signature look from Fashion houses like Balenciaga, Givenchy, Louis Vuitton and more.

Fashioning a sack out of cotton or leather materials is nothing new, humans have been doing it forever, but what we know as the tote bag–resplendent in its minimalism and radiant in its practicality—traces its origins back to the verb “to tote”. Popularized in the 17th century, the verb “tote” meant “to carry by hand” or, less gracefully put, “to lug.” While tote bags are traditionally made of canvas, there are no actual limitations to what a tote bag is made of. As long as it can be lugged around, it’s a tote bag!

  1. LUGGAGE BAG – 

For trips away, whether on a plane or via a car or train, when you need to carry more stuff with you, nothing beats rolling luggage. It’s too convenient not having to lug around your luggage on your back or by carrying it by the handles when this bag can be gliding effortlessly next to you.

  1. TOILETRY KIT or DOPP BAG – 

The final bag or piece of luggage you need is a Toiletry Kit or  Dopp kit for all your toiletries and grooming essentials. These are great for trips or for any sort of travel. They keep your stuff organized, are sophisticated-looking and are just a joy to use.

item.title: Rath Yatra Festival
item.dc:creator: Sukanta Pal
item.description: Before explaining what is Rath Yatra Festival(ରଥଯାତ୍ରା) or Festival of...
item.content:encoded:
Before explaining what is Rath Yatra Festival(ରଥଯାତ୍ରା) or Festival of Chariots need to understand the history of this Hindu festival, the main deity that is worshipped during the Rath yatra Festival, that is Krishna’s (an incarnation of Vishnu also a major deity in Hinduism) avatar Lord Jagannath (​​​Friend of the Universe) with his brother Balarama & sister Subhadra.

Rath Yatra Festival(ରଥଯାତ୍ରା) or Chariot Festival happened every year month June or July (monsoon season), it’s a Hindu festival associated with Lord Jagannath held in Puri (the state of Odisha, India) It is the oldest Ratha Yatra, The festival commemorates Jagannath’s annual visit to Gundicha Temple (maternal aunt’s home/Masir Bari) aka as Shoja Rath and Return Journey to his Temple aka as Ulto Rath.

Rituals/Tradition – Not only in Puri, Odisha this Rath Yatra Festival happened in the World with their respective history of this festival. So it will vary in terms of Rath Design and the process of celebrating it. The basic ritual followed everywhere, Rath Yatra’s morning the Triad Deities of Jagannath bring from the main temple with escort and seated respective one Single Rath or separate 3 Rath or Chariots for respective deities. After that, it’s driven by devote/people with help of a rope attached in front of the Chariot and controlled the direction by the respective person standing from Chariot. This procession stopped by many locations so that people can do offer puja also control the road traffic. After reached the destination stayed 1 Week or 8/9 days and then return journey called as Ulto Rath arrive at the main temple. On this occasion, the most popular Rather Mela (Rath fair) happened on the premises & lots of programmes, puja and all performed. Main food attraction of Rather Mela is Jilapi/জিলিপি (Jalebi Sweet) and Papor Vaja/পাঁপড় ভাজা (papad fry).

List of Kolkata’s Rath Yatra Festival

  • ISKCON (International Society for Krishna Consciousness) Rath Yatra
  • Bonedi Barir Rath Yatra Festival
  • Puri’s Rath Yatra Festival 2022

Rath Yatra Festival Dates by Year 

The Triad Deities of Jagannath 

Apart from Jagannath other two deities are from the left Balarama (बलराम) is an elder brother of Jagannath(Krishna), also known as Haladhara, Halayudha, Baladeva, Balabhadra and Sankarshana. From Center Subhadra (सुभद्रा) is a younger sister of Jagannath(Krishna) and Balarama and Right Side Jagannath himself.

History of Jagannath, Hinduism – The appearance of a god as a human (Incarnation) like Jesus Christ, was an influencer and Founder of Christianity likewise Krishna for Hinduism (Unlike other religions, Hinduism has no one founder but is instead a fusion of various beliefs). After the death of that human/Story, we were influenced and worshipped in different forms like idols, Photos and all, because of their legacy and great contribution.

item.title: Heritage Metro Railway of Kolkata
item.dc:creator: Sukanta Pal
item.description: Kolkata Metro or Heritage Metro of Kolkata is one of...
item.content:encoded:
Kolkata Metro or Heritage Metro of Kolkata is one of the proud moments of Kolkata(Calcutta) People. The Metro Railway, Calcutta on Sunday (24th October 2021) formally bade farewell to non-AC rakes, some of which have been in service since its inception as the country’s first underground railway in 1984. Which started services 37 years ago between Esplanade and Bhowanipore (at present Netaji Bhavan station), a distance of 3.40 km, now covers 31.3 km.

Kolkata – the city of joy, the cultural capital of India, and a city home to millions. The city that is packed with the impressions of colonial era blended with a touch of modern amenities, is also the third most populated urban area in India. As industries flourished, Calcutta got squeezed by its limited road space. With overflowing traffic all around, the city was starving with its lack of efficiency. That’s when the Metro Railway was conceptualized. Aiming to keep the city moving, we started building India’s First Ever Metro Rail!

But the idea of a metro rail is not new! As can be seen in the pioneer, the metro railway in Calcutta was conceptualized much earlier in 1921. As the situation deteriorated, the idea was revived in 1969 with the help of the Metropolitan Transport Project under the Ministry of Railways. Long before the recent years of India’s metro revolution, Metro Railway was formed under the Ministry of Railways to provide world-class amenities to Kolkata. Although the aim was promising, construction of such a project was very challenging in India back then. With fund crunches and lack of technology, we faced a huge difficulty in constructing your North-South Metro. But with the help of our German, Hungarian and Russian friends, we started materializing the project to make it a reality. With no standards provides, it was never easy to build the metro on our own. It took some time extra, but we couldn’t hold our excitement as the North-South Metro gradually took its shape. With struggles and quenches, work was completed. With the help of BHEL and NGEF, we brought indigenously developed metro trains that were manufactured in Chennai by the ICF. Thus, with the blessings of the people, the Kolkata Metro was dedicated to the service of the nation on 24th October, 1984.

37 years ago, when the first metro arrived at Esplanade and opened its automatic sliding doors, people were awestruck! In a time when India still had Steam Engines chugging around, people only heard of the London Underground but never imagined something similar. Therefore, we soon acquired the tag of ‘India’s First, Kolkata’s Pride’. Soon after, things became better! As we expanded from Tollygunge to Dumdum, our metro took the entire load of the city! Our indigenous technologies soon proved to be the best alternative to Trams, Buses, Taxis, and whatever that spoiled the streets of Calcutta. Non-airconditioned and too noisy, but as our trains cruised through the tunnels, people proudly lauded us for making their lives easier!

As we started with only 4 coaches per rake, metro’s immense footfall forced us to upgrade to 8 cars. Carrying lakhs of people through the tunnels every single day, Metro Railway Kolkata soon became a national symbol of success! From Delhi to Bangalore, from Mumbai to Chennai, cities across India took inspiration from our success and desperately planned their own metro projects.

With the government’s sanction, we gradually went extra-miles to connect the southern fringes of New Garia. So, our ageing fleet of Non-AC trains became insufficient. Finally, with the inauguration of metro services up to Kavi Subhash, two fully Air Conditioned Metro rakes were inducted into service on 7th October 2010. As we ran our metro with the ageing Non-AC fleet, our commuters kept on skipping the trains in search of an AC Metro. Finally, the day has come when you don’t have to wait for an AC Metro! Metro Railway Kolkata proudly announces that non ac metro services have been permanently discontinued. As we have enough AC metro rakes, it is time to bid a farewell to Non-AC metro. Noisy tunnels and humid commutes are gone forever! After today, their doors will never open; their lights will never glow; the fans will never noise! The tales of Non-AC Metros will be permanently transferred to the pages of history!

As we expand our services to New Town in the East, Howrah Maidan in the west, Airport in the north and Joka in the extreme south, we pledge to provide cool and comfortable services to a station near you! Future is as glorious as the past! Commute anywhere in a matter of minutes with our modern facilities! In Future, we’re bringing India’s first underwater metro near Howrah Bridge, the largest underground metro station at the Airport and the deepest underground metro station at Howrah. Joining Sealdah with Howrah, Kalighat with Dakshineswar, Eco Park with Victoria and Barasat with Joka, your futuristic metro will revolutionize Kolkata’s Transport System!

item.title: Karva Chauth Celebrations in West Bengal
item.dc:creator: Sukanta Pal
item.description: Karwa Chauth (करवा चौथ) is one of the major festivals,...
item.content:encoded:
Karwa Chauth (करवा चौथ) is one of the major festivals, celebrated widely throughout the country, in such pandemic situations at home, abiding all covid safety norms, in new normal way. Its said that while gods had a battle with Ashuras, the Goddess Parvati, Lakshmi, Saraswati and others kept fast for their husbands and wished for their victory over evil power. Since then women on this day fast and pray for their husband’s long life and safety.

It’s a festival celebrated by Hindu women from the Indian Subcontinent on the fourth day after Purnima (a full moon) in the month of Kartika. Like many Hindu festivals, Karwa Chauth is based on the lunisolar calendar which accounts for all astronomical positions, especially positions of the moon which is used as a marker to calculate important dates. The festival falls on the fourth day after the full moon, in the Hindu lunisolar calendar month of Kartik. On Karwa Chauth, married women, especially in North India, observe fast from sunrise to moonrise for the safety and longevity of their husbands. The Karwa Chauth fast is traditionally celebrated in the states of Delhi, Haryana, Rajasthan, Gujarat Punjab, Jammu and Kashmir, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Himachal Pradesh and Madhya Pradesh. It is celebrated as Atla Tadde in Andhra Pradesh.

In a New Normal Way, in a remote village of Bihar, where I went today to document and meanwhile took some short clippings, which I compiled with one of my favourite karwa chauth songs for you all to take a look at the rituals women perform for their husbands.

item.description: This time of the year when we officially celebrate with...
item.content:encoded:
This time of the year when we officially celebrate with firecrackers or crackers(Bazi). Happy to see that now most of the sound firecrackers are very less popular and people also avoid buying them, only celebrating with the lights. Kali Puja, Diwali, Dev Deepawali or any other name you call it; this festival boasts the making of lights, that can be crackers, electric lights or Diya and many more. This is the prime time of selling and manufacturing firecrackers or Bazi market increase. 

Chamahati and Nungi(also Called Nangi) are famous for making firecrackers (Manufacturing hub) of West Bengal. They are making Green Firecrackers for over a decade, due to some restrictions and flood now production very less in terms of the previous year. Champahati’s Haral Village is the maker of crackers when Diwali or kali puja near they sell their crackers roadside temporary shops and also those who have permanent shops sell them also. Those crackers made in Champahati are very cheap but other crackers imported from are not so cheap because those are not produced here. If you want to buy some crackers or wholesale purpose visit Champahati Rail Staton, it’s nearby Champahati Bazi Market.

Nungi is a neighbourhood in the Maheshtala of the South 24 Parganas district in the Indian state of West Bengal. It is a part of the area covered by the Kolkata Metropolitan Development Authority (KMDA). Champahati is a census town and a gram panchayat within the jurisdiction of the Baruipur police station in the Baruipur community development block in the Baruipur subdivision of the South 24 Parganas district in the Indian state of West Bengal. They now make eco-friendly crackers that anyone can buy and easy to sell and top of it environmentally friendly. Slowly now the trend of Sky lantern or fanush flying followed by traditional Diya is more popular when comes to celebrating Diwali or Kali Puja in Kolkata. 

On this occasion of Kali Puja, a few bonedi houses (Bonedi Barir Kali Puja Kolkata or Fanush Bari) of Kolkata or heritage houses of Calcutta flying fanush or hot air balloon in Kolkata (Calcutta). The most popular house is Bholanath Dham Family (33/2, Beadon Street, Kolkata – 700006), after Durga Puja, they started making fanush at their home’s Thakurdalan, it takes time to make because those fanush are big in size also designed fanush lots of paper cutting involved, that’s why it’s very time consuming to make lots of patience and skill is required to make one good fanush or hot air balloon. Every year on the day of Kali Puja Afternoon (around 2-3 pm) they started flying fanush or hot air balloons from their courtyard along with fanush enthusiasts, friends and family; fanush makers are also there for support and help to make it successful. This spectacular fanush flying event was documented by photographers; day by day the number of photographers increase, it’s great to see that fanush flying becoming a trend in Kolkata. 

Started with Fanush Flying event in Kolkata, now Sky lantern or Chinese Lantern are very much popular for eco-friendly and opportunity for great profile picture or Facebook DP, it’s looking good and happy exercise for all of them. Different communities like Photographers, clubs, Residencies or Housing complex people now take it seriously and fanush flying or Sky lantern now trend in Kolkata. In Kolkata we called fanush (Manush Fanush) because it’s started or we know from Bholanath Dham Ajoy Dutt’s house, that’s why that name referred from since then. 

Kolkata Fireworks store or shop previously held at Sahid Minar Ground like fair for selling crackers on The occasion of Diwali and Kali Puja, now happened on Sithir More Circus Ground.

item.title: Experimenter Gallery Kolkata
item.dc:creator: Sukanta Pal
item.description: Kolkata’s (Calcutta) is one of the finest and heritage Gallery...
item.content:encoded:
Kolkata’s (Calcutta) is one of the finest and heritage Gallery called Experimenter. It was co-founded by Prateek & Priyanka Raja in 2009, with a multidisciplinary approach, the gallery is an incubator for an ambitious and challenging contemporary practice. The program represents some of the most critical contemporary artists worldwide. 

The program, rooted in dialogue and dissent, is considered to be a ‘pace-setter’ for its region, and extends from exhibition-making to knowledge creation, through regular talks, performances, workshops and through its much acclaimed, annual curatorial intensive – Experimenter Curators’ Hub. A second, more ambitious space was added in 2018, marking a deeper inquisition into the gallery’s realm of interest. The gallery attempts to expand the scope of contemporary practice beyond the ambit of its expected role. In 2016, its artist-book publishing wing was launched followed by the Experimenter Learning Program in 2018 which enables learning in fields of contemporary and performing arts, curatorship, film, writing, language and social culture. In 2019, Experimenter Outpost, an iterative exhibitions program outside the physical gallery temporarily inhabiting disused, characterful spaces were formed. 2020 marked the beginning of Experimenter Labs an inclusive, experimental and multi-dimensional online platform in addition to the onsite gallery programming.

EXPERIMENTER – HINDUSTAN ROAD is housed in a 1930’s old-style building in Kolkata’s Gariahat area with ceiling heights of over 12 feet, the space in the centre of the main gallery an 8 feet square by 2 feet deep recess (originally the courtyard of the old building) make the space completely experimental in nature in line with the gallery philosophy. The depression, ideal for installations and performances, is flexible and can be made even with the floor if desired.

EXPERIMENTER – BALLYGUNGE PLACE occupies two floors of a carefully restored 1930s building, typical of early 20th-century architecture in Bengal. Redesigned by leading Indian architect Rajeev Agarwal, and lighting design team Lyle Lopez, Experimenter at Ballygunge Place will combine the existing architecture of the building – high ceilings and exquisite mosaic flooring – with a purpose-built structure, offering an interplay between natural and directional lighting systems and state of the art technology for showcasing ambitious contemporary art. The gallery programme includes solo and group shows from internationally and locally based talent, the scope will extend to performances, film, photography, music, lectures, salon-style workshops and discussions.

Experimenter started with a love story. When Prateek Raja told childhood sweetheart Priyanka about his long-held ambition to open a cutting-edge art gallery, she did not hesitate for a second. The then-media manager quit her job, and packed her bags; the couple spent a year meeting artists and plotting their future venture. Experimenter opened in 2009. It has since then established itself as one of India’s leading galleries, boasting two spaces in the country’s cultural capital, Kolkata, and championing the likes of Prabhakar Pachpute, artist collective CAMP, and Naeem Mohaiemen.

item.title: Ganesh Chaturthi Festival in Kolkata
item.dc:creator: Sukanta Pal
item.description: How Kolkata dominant Durga Puja likewise Ganesh Puja Lead by...
item.content:encoded:
How Kolkata dominant Durga Puja likewise Ganesh Puja Lead by Mumbai (Bombay). Most popular and celebrated festival in Mumbai. Nowadays though Kolkata also try to catch the trend and bring idol from Mumbai itself (not ordering from Kumartuli). So this way slowly the number of Ganesh Puja increasing year by year. This Ganesh Puja Started on 10th September 2021. 

These rituals are performed during the 10-day long festival. They are namely Pranapratishhtha, Shhodashopachara, Uttarpuja, and Ganpati Visarjan. The excitement of Ganesh Chaturthi settles in weeks before the festival actually begins. Artisans start preparing clay idols of Ganesha in different poses and sizes.

Now the Shree Siddhivinayak Ganapati Mandir in Kolkata. A Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shri Ganesh. It is located in The 48B Muktaram Babu Street. It is one of the richest temples in India(Mumbai One). 

On the last day of the festival, the tradition of Ganesh Visarjan takes place. The concluding day of the 10-day festival is also popularly known as Anant Chaturdashi. As the word ‘visarjan’ implies, on this day immersion (‘visarjan’ means immersion) of Lord Ganapati’s idol takes place in a river, sea or water body. On the first day of the festival, the devotees mark the beginning of Ganesh Chaturthi with the placement of Lord Ganesha’s idol in their homes, public places and offices. On the last day, the devotees come out in processions carrying the idols of their beloved God and perform immersion.
